title: 107_hr2097
content: The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" is the short title of this Act. It aims to improve child care quality. The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" aims to improve child care quality by emphasizing the importance of early learning and nurturing care for children's growth and development. Research shows that quality early care and education lead to increased cognitive abilities, positive classroom behavior, long-term school success, and economic self-sufficiency. Approximately 13,000,000 children, including 6,000,000 infants and toddlers, receive child care daily, but only 1 in 7 meet quality standards. The cost of full-day child care can range from $4,000 to $10,000 per year, but Federal assistance is limited, making it difficult for many families to afford. Only 1 in 7 child care centers provide care that promotes healthy development, while 1 in 8 centers pose threats to children's safety and health. Full-day child care costs $4,000 to $10,000 per year. Federal assistance is limited, making it hard for many families to afford. Families with a monthly income under $1,200 spend 25% of their income on child care. State reimbursement rates for child care providers are too low for quality care accessibility. State reimbursement rates for child care providers are too low, impacting the quality of care children receive and limiting access to quality child care for families. Low rates force providers to cut corners, such as reducing staff, training, and educational activities. State reimbursement rates for child care providers are too low, leading to reduced quality of care for children. This includes cutting staff, training, and educational activities, which can result in delayed skills and increased aggression in children. Higher payment rates can improve quality by attracting qualified staff, providing training, and maintaining a safe environment. Increased payment rates lead to higher quality child care by allowing providers to attract and retain qualified staff, provide salary increases and professional training, maintain a safe environment, and purchase necessary supplies. The purpose of this Act is to enhance the quality and accessibility of child care through increased payment rates. The Act aims to provide incentive grants to improve the quality of child care. Funding for improving the quality of child care is authorized with $500,000,000 appropriated for fiscal year 2002. Appropriation of $500,000,000 for grants to improve child care quality is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funds available for subsequent years. Amendments are made to the use of block grant funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. Amendments are made to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to improve the quality of child care services. Amendments to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 aim to enhance the quality of child care services by inserting new sections. "Amendments to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 include grants to improve the quality of child care." The Secretary will use appropriated funds to make grants to eligible States for child care services based on market rates surveys conducted within the past 2 years. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must have conducted a market rates survey for child care services within the past 2 years and submit an application to the Secretary. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must submit an application to the Secretary with details of the methodology and results of the State market rates survey conducted. Each grant application must include details of the State market rates survey methodology and results, a plan to increase payment rates from the baseline, and how rates will be increased based on the survey results. The State must demonstrate progress in maintaining increased payment rates through activities funded under the subchapter to receive annual payments. Additionally, the State must conduct a market rates survey at least once every 2 years to inform how payment rates will be increased. The State must show progress in maintaining increased payment rates through activities funded under the subchapter and conduct a market rates survey every 2 years to inform payment rate increases. State contributions are required for eligibility to receive a grant under this section. The State must provide cash contributions of at least 25 percent of the costs for activities under subsection (d) to be eligible for a grant. Federal funds cannot be counted towards the State contributions. The State must provide cash contributions for activities under subsection (d) to be eligible for a grant. Federal funds cannot be included in State contributions. Allotted funds must be used to increase child care assistance payment rates. An eligible State receiving a grant must increase child care assistance payment rates up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Once achieving this, the State can use the funds for other activities approved by the Secretary. The State can use grant funds for activities that enhance child care services, as long as payment rates reach the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Amounts received should supplement, not supplant, other funds. The State must submit information on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality and accessibility. The Secretary will submit reports to Congress. The Secretary will submit biennial reports to Congress on the impact of increased payment rates on child care quality and accessibility in the State. The reports will include data from applications as a baseline for tracking progress in maintaining higher payment rates. The term 'payment rate' refers to reimbursement rates for subsidized child care providers. Amendments are made to sections regarding payments and allotments under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. Amendments are made to section 658O of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990, specifically in subsections (a), (b)(1), and (e). Amendments to section 658O of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 include changes to subsections (a), (b)(1), and (e), such as inserting references to "section 658B" and modifying language regarding allotments.
